moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Bxc6 dx: The character of the position is now clear. White has acquired a K-side pawn majority and left Black with a Q-side one that is badly disrupted by the doubled Pawns. Black, however, has the Bishop-pair, which could be put to good use in this open position.
moves.6... Bg4: Black's 6th move was played with the idea of exchanging the Knight and breaking up White's K side Pawns. This, however, is not a logical plan, as White's doubled pawns would be more mobile than those of Black.
moves.7. Nc3 Qxd4: Black renounces his plan to disrupt White's Pawns.
moves.8. Nxd4 O-O-O 9. Be3 Bb4 10. Nde2: After 10 P-B3 BxN ch 11 PxB B-Q2 12 K-B2, unlike Bishops would be left after a possible exchange of Knights, giving Black good drawing chances.
moves.10... Bxe2: Black gives up his only trump, the two Bishops, to saddle White with doubled Pawns, but his prospects on the Q-side are in now way improved as a result. Correct was 10... N-K2 11 P-B3 B-Q2, and after ...P-KB4 Black can attempt to obtain play with his pieces.
moves.11. Kxe2 Bxc3 12. bxc3: On the K side it is only a matter of time before White produces a passed pawn.
moves.12... Nf6 13. f3 Nd7 14. Rad1 Ne5: Better was 14... P-QN3, to be followed by ...P-QB4 and... N-N1-B3.
moves.15. Rd4 b6 16. f4 Nd7 17. Rhd1 c5 18. Rd: Black thinks that by holding on to his Rooks he will be able to better meet the opposing Pawn advance:. The problem is that his King is cut off from where it is needed most, on the K side. Better was 19... RxR 20 RxR K-Q1.
moves.20. f5: The normal move, 20 P-K5, would have been a mistake in this case because the KBP could not then advance without leaving the KP en prise.
moves.20... f6 21. g4 Re7 22. Bf4 Rhe8 23. Re3: Black has no means of improving his position.
moves.25. h4 Nc4 26. Re2 Rf7 27. Rg1 Kd7: Somewhat better is 27... P-N3, but White would then play 28 BPxP RPxP 29 PxP RxBP 30 R-N5!, with P-R5 to follow.
moves.29. h6 fxg5: Obviously not 29... P-N3 30 BPxP RPxP 31 PxP RxBP 32 P-K5 R/3-K3 33 R-Q2.
moves.30. Rxg5 g6: This loses a Pawn, but after 30... PxP 31 R-R5 the position is hopeless for Black in view of White's two united passed Pawns.
